newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan Jan money growth seen sign of slow economy.
newsitem.headline: Japan Jan money growth seen sign of slow economy.

text.p: Japan"s money supply growth of 3.1 percent in January was largely a reflection of continuing sluggishness in Japan"s economy that suppressed both bank lending and private spending, economists said on Tuesday.
Some added that money supply growth could well diminish even further, edging down below three percent after the start of the 1997 fiscal year in April.
The Bank of Japan (BOJ) said earlier on Tuesday that Japan"s broadly defined money supply average of M2 plus certificates of deposit (CDs) grew a preliminary 3.1 percent year on year in January.
This was unchanged from the revised figure of 3.1 percent growth in December 1996.

Economists agreed that a key factor behind slow money growth appeared to be weak bank lending, citing last week"s BOJ figures indicating that the average balance of lending by 149 Japanese banks dipped 0.2 percent in January from a year earlier, the fourth month in a row of year-on-year declines.

"Without growth in bank lending, it"s impossible to expect overall growth in money supply. The low bank lending figures definitely reflect the weakness of the economy," said Yasuhiko Ushikubo, an economist with the Industrial Bank of Japan.

Ryo Sawai, an economist with Yamaichi Research Institute, agreed. Noting that the 3.1 percent figure had been slightly lower than expected, he added that it seemed to indicate a subtle negative shift in expectations for the Japanese economy.
"Although we had been seeing a slight pickup of investment in plant and equipment, this has been offset by a general decline in private spending," he said.
A BOJ official told reporters that the figures were in line with the central bank"s prediction that money supply growth would remain above three percent from January through March this year.
Although some economists said this was possible, most agreed that money supply growth is likely to follow a downward course once the new fiscal year begins.

"A break below three percent would not be at all strange, given the state of the economy, with bank lending likely to decrease even more," said Kyohei Morita, an economist at Nomura Research Institute.
